Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 10:07PM Sunris wrote: I took Taxol also.  For me, I found it to be rather easy.  I never not once vomitted & never not once became nauseated.  I did lose my hair after my 3rd treatment.  I experienced some fairly moderate fatigue.   After 9 treatments of the 12, my treatments were discontinued because I developed neuropathy.  My Onc said that the neuropathy can become permanent therefore she made the decision to no longer give it to me.  In all honesty, I would say Taxol was a breeze compared to FAC.  I have heard of many that have neulasta shots, but it was never even mentioned to me and quite honestly, I'm thankful as the side effects sound horrible.   My counts went really low, but they always recouped fairly quickly.  Oh, and I did have some slight muscle/joint pain? while on Taxol.  Best of luck on your journey.
Posts.Title: paclitaxel weekly gonnabstrong unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 12:05AM Sunris wrote: My hair fell out after the 3rd treatment....( thinned first....then about week 4 was so thin I opted to shave it all off).   I was not taking anything else while I was taking the Taxol, except the premeds  they give you along with your Taxol , such as dexamethasone ( steroid via IV), and an anti-nausea med, also via IV.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 08:31PM Sunris wrote: Brachial Plexus Signs Are Usually Caused By Tumor Infiltration Or Injury From Radiation Therapy In patients with cancer, brachial plexus signs are usually caused by tumor infiltration or injury from radiation therapy (RT). We analyzed 100 cases of brachial plexopathy to determine which clinical criteria helped differentiate tumor from radiation injury. Seventy-eight patients had tumor and 22 had radiation injury. Severe pain occurred in 80% of tumor patients but in only 19% of patients with radiation injury. The lower trunk was involved in 72% of the tumors. Seventy-eight percent of the radiation injuries affected the upper plexus (C5-6). Horner syndrome was more common in tumor, and lymphedema in radiation injury. The time from RT to onset of plexus symptoms, and the dose of RT, also differed.
Posts.Title: radiation-induced brachial plexopathy Erica35 ryder51

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 07:15PM Sunris wrote: Hi Pam,  Sorry to hear that you have had to join this group of sisterhood, but please know that there are many of us out here to provide support.   I too have negative receptors....I am Triple Negative as in my HER  is also negative.  Suemed gave you good advise.  Are you triple negative? Just ER & PR negative ?    If you are Triple Negative I would be more than happy to share with you what I know / have experienced, etc.... Trust me girl, I have done my research and have also found some great places to get answers.   As far as being HER+, I don't have experience with that but I believe one of the differences is that you would be eligible for Herceptin whereas I am not ( being Triple Negative) .... Big hugs, Dawn
